Actual Response: "{'feature': 'compatibility of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'Importing his EQ was a breeze, and using his preset felt as if I was using a different speaker altogether, and it was for the better, no doubt about that.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that importing the custom EQ preset from Oluvs Gadgets was a breeze and using his preset felt like using a different speaker altogether, which was for the better.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: "After careful consideration of my past experience with Ankers speakers (ok but not much more) I had decided to shortlist this speaker. I was skeptical, Ill admit, having scoured the internet for reviews that werent paid advertisements (which is rare unfortunately). But then I came across one particular person who gives honest unpaid reviews, and he actually gave it a gold award, to which I was surprised as much as I was amazed. Watching his review gave me the impetus to buy the Motion 300.", "First impressions with Ankers default signature preset were sub-par; bass was all over the place, highs werent visceral enough to be considered neutral. I feel these signature presets are predicated on pure guess work by Ankers sound people, because they never sound good unfortunately. Not one of the four presets are good, xtra bass is just boosted upper bass, making the sound really quite unpleasant. And balanced, well lets just say, isnt balanced.", "But one of the absolute jewels (kudos to Anker here) of the Soundcore App is the custom EQ feature; not only do you get a 9- band equaliser, you get full-band in addition, giving the end user a level of flexibility that simply isnt heard of with any other brand. Bose dont even give an EQ; Sony give you a three band EQ; LG give you a poor 5 band; JBL gives you a simple dual-band; you get the idea.", "One person in particular, by the name of Oluvs Gadgets gave the speaker a review and made his own custom EQ for the speaker, which happened to impress him so much he have it a rare gold award, on par (at the very least) with Earfuls UBoom L, which has long held the title of best bluetooth speaker for him specifically.", Importing his EQ was a breeze, and using his preset felt as if I was using a different speaker altogether, and it was for the better, no doubt about that., "The sound is accurate and neutral, whilst still delivering on those all important bass notes in more bass prevalent tracks. Low bass is unaffected, and limiting on a speaker of this size. The Harman Pardon Luna is for the bass fans, but strong deep bass doesnt make for an accurate speaker. As with most bluetooth speakers, its reliant on mid-bass, and with Oluvs EQ, it sounds great.", "At the default signature  preset, side by side with my Bose Soundlink Flex, the Bose is too boomy, with its bass overwhelming everything else, but the Motion 300 isnt all that much better; it just sounds muddy and less powerful. Switching to the imported EQ present, its a whole different ball game; it completely leaves the Flex in the dust. Ive decided out of the many speakers I own at this point (XG7, XG300, Motion+, Flex, Beosound A1, Sonos Roam, Earfun UBOOM L, and HK Luna) Im going to primary the Motion 300. For a better experience when everyone isnt in the house, Ill use my GO+ Play 3.", "Now, is this a praise for Anker necessarily? Well in one sense yes, because its managed to outshine every other portable speaker I own, with a custom EQ preset. In another sense, perhaps more importantly, no. As seems to be the case with the Q30 headphones, from which every subsequent model sounded poor, Anker appear to rely on sheer luck when it comes to good sound tuning, i.e., its just a case of luck if their next headphone/speaker sounds good or not. I would hope Anker listen to unbiased reviewers like Oluv, and consider the fact that they have a massive opportunity to be genuine, trustworthy leaders in the headphone and speaker market."

Sound-wise, they are closely alike (though the M300 at 30W rating is higher than the C3 at 20W)!

The C3 has fuller sound in low volume with better lows (bass) and a more balance highs.

The C3 loses its fidelity(?) when the volume is about 70% and above (though age is a factor for the C3).

Review text: The media could not be loaded.                , "Received my Anker Soundcore Motion 300 today. I wasnt impressed with the sound quality, even with the bass on. Tried the recommend Soundcore app, hoping that this would boost my expectations. This was not the case. Having done my own equaliser version, there is treble as well as bass. Ankers equaliser on this has the bass turned up and the treble down in the hope that this would give it a bass improvement...sadly not. Yes, it has a warm feel to it, but sadly lacks the artists vocals on this with the treble being down. The only plus about this, is the fact that its 30 watts of pure sound and with the bass off (which sounds better), youre saving battery life. I have heard better from the likes of JBL and Jams Heavy Metal speaker has a much more punchy bass, considering its only a 20 watt speaker. The Soundcore Motion 300 is ok as a travel speaker, but sadly, it fails to deliver in decent sound quality. The price tag, even at £74.99, is not worth it and I can see the speaker drop down in price between £40-£50 in the next few months."

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'Connectivity. You can even establish a hardwired connection between this speaker and your dedicated source', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The speaker has Bluetooth 5.0 connectivity with the capability of performing in stereo via TWS and can even establish a hardwired connection between the speaker and the dedicated source.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: "  Ebodas Bluetooth shower speaker comes with an IP67 rating, 5-pattern LED lighting, 5-watts of power, and connectivity via Bluetooth 5.0 with TWS and a wired connection.", "Out of the box, this Eboda speaker reminded me of a hockey puck. Ebodas sound puck is wrapped in a removable rubberized skin and has a grill on the top.", "Other than the sound, the first thing I was anxious to try was the water-resistance of the speaker.  While the speaker was on and playing music at max volume I filled a sink full of water then dropped the speaker inside the sink. It floated and reproduced sound just as it did prior to the dunk so I upped the stakes and submerged the speaker. Thats when the sound output dropped significantly. The speaker remained on and wasnt damaged but the output was maybe 10% of its full potential.", "I tested the sound of this speaker in 3 ways: via Bluetooth, via direct hardwired connection and via DAC passthrough connection. After listening to HD and Ultra HD tunes on Amazon Music I settled in with Hotel California from the Eagles. Music within this genre sounds good on this speaker. Afterwards I put the speaker through its paces by listening to the first couple of minutes of the original Iron Man movie. Not only do you get to hear how the speaker handles AC/DCs Back in Black, but there are lots of gunshots and explosions that test the bass response and whether a speaker can reproduce spatial separation. Naturally, this small speaker with only a single driver and no bass port failed on the biggest explosions and directional sound. However, when I listened via DAC passthrough I was pleasantly surprised that this speaker held its own.", Pros, - Value. This speaker is much louder than expected and the sound quality is more than acceptable for something in this price range., - Lighting. This speaker is made with a grill and rubber skin shield the light enough to keep it from being blinding even in a dark environment; an important detail considering there are no brightness settings. There are settings for the lighting effects that are easily accessible through a dedicated button., - Connectivity. This speaker uses Bluetooth 5.0 with the capability of performing in stereo via TWS. You can even establish a hardwired connection between this speaker and your dedicated source., - Battery life. This speaker lasted 8 hours on its first full charge. Since this is probably a speaker I would only use situationally near water I found this runtime more than acceptable., Cons, - Bass. While it improved with extended listening this speaker desperately needed a bass port to bump up lower frequencies., - Charge time. This speaker has a 3-hour charge time., "- Only one connection. This speaker only has one port and Eboda opted for the outdated Micro USB connector. The manufacturer provides two cables in the box. One is a USB-A to Micro USB for charging. The other is a Micro USB to 3.5mm. This short, somewhat challenging to find cable is the only way to hardwire the speaker to an audio source. Because this speaker sounds better when passthrough hardwired through a DAC failing to include a separate headphone jack was an almost unforgivable oversight on Ebodas part.", "Overall, Ebodas sound puck offers good sound and good features at a fair price. The speaker looks nice, has attractive lighting and better average sound when driven with a DAC. Because it lacks a bass port and a dedicated headphone jack this speaker isnt the first small speaker I grab when I want to get in some quality listening but if I am taking a shower, around the pool or at the beach this is the only speaker I use because its built to handle those environments and is loud enough to cut through most of the ambient noise that is common for those places. I wish Amazon allowed half-star grades because this speaker earns a 3.5 out of 5 as its good but could be improved a couple of very minor tweaks."

Review text: Only had this speaker a few weeks, have not used the charge function, only the speaker for music and battery life. I am a music lover and former trumpet player so I know a few things. This speaker is awesome for its size. The bass it outs out and the sound mix is great. And as far as the battery life, I gave it a four star bc this is a “renewed” speaker and I do not know the comparison to a new speaker. I have NO trouble with my battery. Charge it up and it goes 10-12 hours depending on what and how you play it. I don’t short charge my batteries unless no other option. Frequent short charging is not good for these batteries. I like the price for this speaker better at the renewed level, but don’t expect to be disappointed if you buy a new speaker. Highly recommended

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'compatibility of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'The CHARGE 5 also has the capability of daisy chaining to another compatible JBL Bluetooth speaker, thus producing an audio sound and projection that is a comparable, albeit psuedo, performance to a stereo unit.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the JBL CHARGE 5 has the capability of daisy chaining to another compatible JBL Bluetooth speaker, thus producing an audio sound and projection that is a comparable, albeit psuedo, performance to a stereo unit.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: I purchased a different brand of EXTREMELY popular portable speaker a month ago. It was displayed along with a JBL FLIP 6. The Flip 6, I felt, was a significantly inferior product. A month after purchasing the other brand speaker, I then had the opportunity to compare that same model of speaker with the JBL CHARGE 5. The result ... the other brand of speaker went back into its box, and then to its maker!, "This JBL CHARGE 5 is an AMAZINGLY high quality sound system. The look, the feel, the quality of material. and craftsmanship are all TOP SHELF!! The highs are very crisp and the lows arent muffled. The bass REALLY shines at higher volumes.", I also own a larger, 70 watt, portable stereo unit. It has an equalizer function, that is basically a bass boost, and it is about 4 times larger in size than the  40 watt CHARGE 5. When comparing the two of them, the stereo unit does take home the blue ribbon. However, even though the CHARGE 5 is a mono system, it certainly gave the larger unit a run for its money., The CHARGE 5 also has the capability of daisy chaining to another compatible JBL Bluetooth speaker, thus producing an audio sound and projection that is a comparable, albeit psuedo, performance to a stereo unit., I searched out and purchased a case, on AMAZON, for the JBL, along with a protective silicone cradle that included a shoulder strap and a Carabiner clip. I modified the shoulder strap into a handle that works out quite nicely!, "The battery life isnt the greatest, however, it lasts much longer than the average user would normally utilize the speaker through the course of a 24 hour day.", The Bluetooth functionality is awesome. It locked right into the signal and paired up, then connected, in a heart beat. The only REAL negative aspect of this sweet device is the auto power off feature, which is set to power down after an extremely short interval of idleness. This can become a tremendously frustrating nuisance., All and all, I HIGHLY recommend this extremely high quality, elegant looking, well manufactured, water tight, JBL CHARGE 5 portable speaker. It is a bit more of an investment than the its contemporary JBL FLIP series. However, it is far and above the better choice for quality and performance., I do imagine that, if I treat it with care, this well may be the last portable speaker that this ole boy will ever need to buy!!

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'with the partyboost disables any EQ settings you have on the device, and in my opinion degrades/flattens the overall sound quality', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the partyboost disables any EQ settings you have on the device, and in his opinion degrades/flattens the overall sound quality.', 'sentiment': 'negative'}"
Review text: "(I didnt get anything for free/discount/gift/etc for this review, this is all me)", "I was looking for a waterproof/submersible rated (so ip7/ip67) bluetooth speaker (or linkable two) to take on an upcoming river float trip. I dont -plan- on dunking it, but wanted something that would survive a brief swim if the tube overturned/etc. So I purchased two of these (refurb) JBL Charge 5s rated at 40w.", "I already have two w-king x10s (rated as 70w) and -absolutely- love love love them. The bass response is absolutely the best out of anything Ive heard/tested at that power rating/size. I havent heard any other JBL bluetooth speakers (like a boombox 2/3), so I dont know where the x10s would land in the JBL lineup. However since the x10s are only ip6 rated they can only get wet/be splashed, and cannot be submersed (or at least arent rated for it, and I dont want to test that!).", "On -only- the price I paid for each vs sound loudness/quality, I would have to say the x10s are -drastically- better. The x10s have a button for 2 eq options, and theres no change to eq/loudness/quality when you pair two together. But again, those arent submersible.", That said, out of the other 2-3 sets of "cheap" bluetooth ip7 speakers I ordered and returned, these Charge 5s are probably the best out of those. At the same time, those other "cheap" ones were 1/2 the price of a single JBL Charge 5., Pros:, -when used individually, I feel there is no degradation of overall sound quality or distortion up to max volume. It does seem that the bass "tops out" at around 1/2 volume, and any increase in volume after that point only increases mids and highs., "-I really like how you have the option to customize the EQ for the speaker via the app on a smart phone versus only having static presets.  Its only adjustments for low, mid, and high, so its not like the EQ options you have with say Spotify (on an Android at least, its a 7 band EQ), but its better than only 2 preset EQ settings like on the x10.", "-with the party boost (pairing of multiple JBL speakers) you can individually control the volume of each speaker connected, so if someone wants it quieter near them they can have that, while its still blasting on the other speaker. With the X10 the volume (and EQ setting) are linked, so both will always be at the same volume.", "-rated to be completely submersible in up to 3m of water for 30min. So they can not only get splashed, but can be dunked and survive. I havent tested this yet, but will be if I end up keeping these.", Cons:, "-No EQ settings from the on-board speaker controls. Probably not a big deal to most, but if youre say on  river with your phone in a waterproof bag in a cooler, its not the easiest to make on the fly adjustments.", -"by design" the partyboost disables any EQ settings you have on the device, and in my opinion degrades/flattens the overall sound quality. It's really horrible to me. The single speaker goes from sounding pretty decent, to sounding like a tin can on both speakers. I'm extremely disappointed with this. I can recover some quality by using the EQ built into the Spotify app, it's just a pain and you lose some loudness/volume when you boost the bass/treble. Since you can control the volume of each speaker independently, I don't see why JBL doesn't let you use the EQ function independently, but I digress., "-doesnt come with a strap/carrier (at least the refurbished version), and theres no loops/attachment points on the speaker anywhere. I ended up purchasing a silicone case and strap combo so I can attach it/strap it down to a cooler on the float trip.", -not as loud as I was expecting for a "40w" speaker. My Tribit MaxSoundPlus 24w speaker sounds almost as loud as one of these. Maybe my expectations are skewed? I'll try to remember to use my dB meter on all of these after my river trip and report back with those findings., "So Im at a crossroads where Im not sure if Ill keep these two JBLs, or return and try a Boombox 2/3, since Id have just about enough Amazon credit from returning these to get one. Or just get another Tribit as its IP7, but I seem to recall dropping my Tribit and it having a crack.....then again I could get two Tribits for the price of one of these refurb JBLs...."

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'The one other thing is how choppy the Bluetooth can get if u go farther then 20 feet', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the Bluetooth connectivity range is not good as it gets choppy if you go farther than 20 feet from the speaker.', 'sentiment': 'negative'}"
Review text: "ok this is going to be a long a** review because there is to much to say. let me start off with the speaker itself. its boxed super nicely so you know youre in good care. second it may seem like a lot of money but believe me this is an amazing deal. a year or 2 back i got a huge speaker from amazon (the big box ones) but it was only 50 bucks. i thought it was loud. but believe it or not this is as loud if not louder. and the quality of the sound is out of this world. the base is amazing. its sand/water/dust proof. NOW the one tiny thing is its not heavy or anything its a perfect weight butttttttt if you plan to carry it a lot just in your hands it is thick and heavy enough and does not have an amazing grip made for your hands to hold for long times. so its not portable as in walk wherever you want with it in your hands but there are things you can buy for that luckily. NOW if ur setting it down its not going anywhere the grips on the bottom are amazing. its stitched super nicely also its fast and lasts long. so yes its portable.  there is even an app for it its also super durable. ok now its crazy that i am even saying this about it but the charging cord is amazing. believe it or not i never knew this until a bit ago but different USB cords actually dispose of different amounts of electricity and speed and rate of flow of it. so it can be super dangerous to mix up cords. Nowadays luckily most products have safety systems for that. Anyway the dope thing about this is the actual little plastic pices inside where it would plug into a brick is ORANGE. so you can tell its a jbl one. for example, 99% of companies make it black blue and sometimes white. but jbl made it orange so now you know thats your JBL cord. it even comes with a cool little information booklet to tell you about it. so now let me rate for everything out of 10:", portable: 9/10, audio quality: 10/10, base: 10/10, battery life: 10/10, durability: N/A (not fully tested it yet but so far its been a 10/10), packaged: 10/10, price: 10/10, weight: (not really a way to judge this but its a tiny over 2 pounds so about what i  thought so since it did not super exceed weight expectations 9/10), overall: 9.5/10, what i would rate other competitors on average: 7.5/10, do note this can actually be a dangerous speaker around younger people and pets and even adults because it does actually get really loud and over time this is very damaging to your ears. i really could write a million more things but i am in high school so i have to get back to homework now while listening to music. (really this can be used for anything and even though this is refurbished i promise you you would never know really i have owned a new one.), EDIT:, Soooo we did end up having a few problems. So one thing is the sand. It’s amazing in water but in the sand it will get only a few but still a few pieces of it stuck in the grills/netting. The one other thing is how choppy the Bluetooth can get if u go farther then 20 feet. Now idk if that’s because I have a iPhone XR (now we are on the 15 so 5 or 4 gens old if apple had skipped a year in between) I would still give a 5 stars since after a week I did manage to get the sand out with the point of a super sharp knife. But I have no idea about the Bluetooth thing. It’s pretty annoying as I saw somewhere it should do wayyyyy farther than that but again it could be my phone. I will give an update number 2 after trying with different phones and seeing if that fixes it. Still 100% recommend it’s still portable and super loud. Oh but if you have young ones or even other adults tell them to not touch the subs on each side of the speaker (the things that bounce in and out with base to help creat it and amplify it.) it’s very bad to touch those and it will damage it either over time or instantly. Some 3rd parties have made nets to cover that area if you have ones that don’t listen I would invest in one. An amazing products still. JBL has mastered audio. The entire family loves it., EDIT 2: ok this is to good. so when i first ordered it it accidentally went to my moms card. i offered to pay her back and but she said no and said as soon as it arrived we are returning. fast forward to my 1st edit she loves it blah blah blah everyone loves it people come up to me say it so good they love it they want it. but wait it gets so much better. NOWWWW my mom wants one for x mas. she told me this morning she has fallen in love with it so much and now wants one. this thing is the most addictive product ever. its hard to explain sound quality. you just have to experience amazing sound quality to love and want good sound quality. trust me if my mom now loves this she really love it. i am in my mid-teens and my mom not in my entire life has ever said she wants something for x mas that i own and that she wanted to return. this is serious stuff right here i promise you will want it. your entire family will., Now i will say that after having it for about 1 month (close enough) and carrying it so much if you not a somewhat strong/ young person it will get tiring on you are really quick to hold it for long periods of time. but you can go pick yourself up a $15 case for it with a handle/strap. I am now changing the new overall rating., JBL Charge 5 New overall rating: 9.8/10, Compared to other similar models and prices: 10/10

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'portability of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'NOW if ur setting it down its not going anywhere the grips on the bottom are amazing. its stitched super nicely also its fast and lasts long. so yes its portable.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the speaker is portable and has amazing grips on the bottom that prevent it from moving around. It is also fast and lasts long. ', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: "ok this is going to be a long a** review because there is to much to say. let me start off with the speaker itself. its boxed super nicely so you know youre in good care. second it may seem like a lot of money but believe me this is an amazing deal. a year or 2 back i got a huge speaker from amazon (the big box ones) but it was only 50 bucks. i thought it was loud. but believe it or not this is as loud if not louder. and the quality of the sound is out of this world. the base is amazing. its sand/water/dust proof. NOW the one tiny thing is its not heavy or anything its a perfect weight butttttttt if you plan to carry it a lot just in your hands it is thick and heavy enough and does not have an amazing grip made for your hands to hold for long times. so its not portable as in walk wherever you want with it in your hands but there are things you can buy for that luckily. NOW if ur setting it down its not going anywhere the grips on the bottom are amazing. its stitched super nicely also its fast and lasts long. so yes its portable.  there is even an app for it its also super durable. ok now its crazy that i am even saying this about it but the charging cord is amazing. believe it or not i never knew this until a bit ago but different USB cords actually dispose of different amounts of electricity and speed and rate of flow of it. so it can be super dangerous to mix up cords. Nowadays luckily most products have safety systems for that. Anyway the dope thing about this is the actual little plastic pices inside where it would plug into a brick is ORANGE. so you can tell its a jbl one. for example, 99% of companies make it black blue and sometimes white. but jbl made it orange so now you know thats your JBL cord. it even comes with a cool little information booklet to tell you about it. so now let me rate for everything out of 10:", portable: 9/10, audio quality: 10/10, base: 10/10, battery life: 10/10, durability: N/A (not fully tested it yet but so far its been a 10/10), packaged: 10/10, price: 10/10, weight: (not really a way to judge this but its a tiny over 2 pounds so about what i  thought so since it did not super exceed weight expectations 9/10), overall: 9.5/10, what i would rate other competitors on average: 7.5/10, do note this can actually be a dangerous speaker around younger people and pets and even adults because it does actually get really loud and over time this is very damaging to your ears. i really could write a million more things but i am in high school so i have to get back to homework now while listening to music. (really this can be used for anything and even though this is refurbished i promise you you would never know really i have owned a new one.), EDIT:, Soooo we did end up having a few problems. So one thing is the sand. It’s amazing in water but in the sand it will get only a few but still a few pieces of it stuck in the grills/netting. The one other thing is how choppy the Bluetooth can get if u go farther then 20 feet. Now idk if that’s because I have a iPhone XR (now we are on the 15 so 5 or 4 gens old if apple had skipped a year in between) I would still give a 5 stars since after a week I did manage to get the sand out with the point of a super sharp knife. But I have no idea about the Bluetooth thing. It’s pretty annoying as I saw somewhere it should do wayyyyy farther than that but again it could be my phone. I will give an update number 2 after trying with different phones and seeing if that fixes it. Still 100% recommend it’s still portable and super loud. Oh but if you have young ones or even other adults tell them to not touch the subs on each side of the speaker (the things that bounce in and out with base to help creat it and amplify it.) it’s very bad to touch those and it will damage it either over time or instantly. Some 3rd parties have made nets to cover that area if you have ones that don’t listen I would invest in one. An amazing products still. JBL has mastered audio. The entire family loves it., EDIT 2: ok this is to good. so when i first ordered it it accidentally went to my moms card. i offered to pay her back and but she said no and said as soon as it arrived we are returning. fast forward to my 1st edit she loves it blah blah blah everyone loves it people come up to me say it so good they love it they want it. but wait it gets so much better. NOWWWW my mom wants one for x mas. she told me this morning she has fallen in love with it so much and now wants one. this thing is the most addictive product ever. its hard to explain sound quality. you just have to experience amazing sound quality to love and want good sound quality. trust me if my mom now loves this she really love it. i am in my mid-teens and my mom not in my entire life has ever said she wants something for x mas that i own and that she wanted to return. this is serious stuff right here i promise you will want it. your entire family will., Now i will say that after having it for about 1 month (close enough) and carrying it so much if you not a somewhat strong/ young person it will get tiring on you are really quick to hold it for long periods of time. but you can go pick yourself up a $15 case for it with a handle/strap. I am now changing the new overall rating., JBL Charge 5 New overall rating: 9.8/10, Compared to other similar models and prices: 10/10

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'compatibility of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'I usually work 7 hour shifts and this little speaker can last that long no problem -- and at full volume. Seen a lot of comments about poor battery life and Ive been experiencing no such problem.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that he has been using the speaker for 7 hour shifts and it has been lasting that long without any issues. He also mentioned that he has seen a lot of comments about poor battery life but he has not experienced any such problem.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: As the description says, this Bluetooth speaker is 24W (internally x2 12W speakers). The reason why the sound is "quieter" as other commenters here have stated is because they are forward-facing, not omnidirectional. This means you have to "point and shoot" in a sense to maximize its volume. Also, they're only 12W speakers individually inside of an enclosure and wired together, which means you're going to get appropriate sound based on this corresponding speaker capacity., "That said, I bought two of these and I take one to work with me to use with a mp3 player while the other charges. Then if the mood or fancy strikes me, Ill occasionally pair them together for surround sound when watching a movie on my mini-pc. The Bluetooth connection has yet to drop or produce any strange sounds or static or what-have-you.", "Long-pressing volume up skips to the next track, long-pressing the volume down skips back to the beginning of the current track (press again for the previous track). Pretty stock and standard. By default the RGB lights come on, which I personally dont care about. Theyre easily turned off by double-tapping on the M mode key (twice to turn off completely). Holding mode key down for a full 7 seconds factory resets it, if you encounter any particularly weird issues.", "I usually work 7 hour shifts and this little speaker can last that long no problem -- and at full volume. Seen a lot of comments about poor battery life and Ive been experiencing no such problem. Push comes to shove, you can plug a power bank directly into it while its playing and youll keep bum-bum-bumming your way through music land. ;-) The volume itself is definitely directly tied to the audio device itself. What I usually do is lower the volume level of my mp3 player down to the lowest volume level, sync the speaker and then use the speakers volume up button to get it to my desired volume level. Do note that the speaker will give you a couple of very loud beeps in quick sequence when youve hit its upper limit -- dont let it scare you!", And for those interested:  FM radio works pretty well from my mp3 player piped to it via Bluetooth, though I can understand how it might sound "tinny" to some who are used to listening to FM radio directly and not being broadcast wirelessly. :-), I'm in agreement with some of my fellow reviwers that this speaker is certainly not worth $160 retail as stated, but at its "sale" price currently even if the retail value were cut in half... the speaker is still very decent for its performance to price ratio. It charges a touch on the slow side is about my only complaint. Otherwise, quality speaker that I'd recommend if you're in the market and on a budget.

Review text: This speaker was a gift for my birthday. The sound quality is amazing. It’s small & lightweight enough to fit in my pool/beach bag. However, the battery life is horrible. Packaging says 8-12 hours of play for a fully charged battery. The most I ever got was 2 hours. I contacted Bose thinking I had a dud battery but apparently if you use the speaker outside & at full volume, the most you’ll get from the battery life is 2 hours. The battery didn’t even make it through my birthday party and had to be placed on a charger. Such a shame because I love the sound quality but can’t justify the price for a 2 hour battery life. I contacted Bose and got no where so I retuned the speaker. If you don’t mind only having 2 hours of battery life, this is a great speaker - just not one you could enjoy at the beach or pool for the day.

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'Bose couldve hit it out of the park with these speakers by offering full mobile support for stereo pairing.  Instead, they chose to only support smartphone stereo streaming, which is only a fraction of their customer use cases.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that Bose could have offered full mobile support for stereo pairing but instead they only supported smartphone stereo streaming which is only a fraction of their customer use cases.', 'sentiment': 'negative'}"
Review text: "Bose couldve hit it out of the park with these speakers by offering full mobile support for stereo pairing.  Instead, they chose to only support smartphone stereo streaming, which is only a fraction of their customer use cases.", The Bose Soundlink speakers are a fantastic option for those seeking high-quality sound in a portable form factor. The sound from these speakers is excellent and fills a room with ease. However, the experience of linking two speakers via smartphone for stereo is sorely disappointing. The linking process is cumbersome and requires multiple attempts to connect the speakers properly, which can be very frustrating., Additionally, Bose chose to only support smartphones for stereo, so these speakers cannot be used to stream stereo from something like a MacBook - my primary want! This is a significant limitation for those who prefer to use something other than a smartphone for their audio streaming needs., Furthermore, on the Apple smartphone front the Bose iOS app is poorly designed and difficult to use. It does not consistently connect two speakers for stereo playback, which is frustrating and adds to the overall poor connectivity experience., In comparison, Sonos and Apple products offer a seamless and intuitive connectivity experience, which is what consumers expect and - honestly - deserve. The excellent sound quality of the Bose Soundlink speakers is significantly overshadowed by the frustrating software connectivity experience. Overall, while the sound quality is impressive, the connectivity experience might turn out to be a refundable violation for you., "Bottom line: If you want to stream stereo from your mobile computer, YOU CANNOT USE a pair of these speakers - they will not work with Bose offering customers support for notebook computers, full stop. If you want to stream stereo from your smartphone, know that youll be forced to sleuth out a step-by-step process involving buttons on the speakers and buttons on your smartphone that pair two speakers - the app isnt smart enough to just connect, seamlessly, every time. Also note that even if you do figure out a process, the speakers can be finicky and refuse to see acknowledge each other, for whatever reason."

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'portability of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'If my primary need was portability I would have kept them, but it’s not.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that he would have kept the speakers if his primary need was portability, but it is not.', 'sentiment': 'neutral'}"
Review text: There are a lot of bluetooth speakers to choose from and I think the choice comes down to how you plan to use it (i.e. backpacking vs in home). The Bose is a great choice if you need portability. I wanted to use them in the home to listen to music while working out…and I ended up buying two. One speaker didn’t fill the room nearly as well as two., Connectivity was simple, and I could use them in “party mode” or “stereo mode” as linked speakers which was great and helped fill the room. Sound was pretty good and they could perform well enough at loud enough., It’s a tough choice, but I am returning them (to costco). The reason is that the quality of sound is dependent on the song. It’s mostly pretty good but bass gets muddled at times.  If my primary need was portability I would have kept them, but it’s not. My home audio system is upstairs and I really just want home speakers downstairs where I work out. So, I’m going to try the Klipsch bluetooth reference speakers (on super sale currently) that have higher wattage.

This is what they had to say:", -------, "Based on the information you provided, the two Soundcore 2 you own are of different generations, with one being A3105014, and the other A3105015 ("4" and "5" stands for the generation of the speaker). As only two upgraded Soundcore 2 of the same generation can pair with each other. As these two are two upgraded Soundcore 2 speakers of different generations (though the same model), they cannot pair with each other.  So it's not something you are not doing right, or if there is anything wrong with your speakers.", --------, "So beware, you may end up receiving different generations of this device and then they wont be compatible with each other and will not stereo pair. Theres no way to differentiate this when you make the purchase, the produce I bought was the same as I bought before and all the descriptions/titles are the same. This is deceptive marketing and Im very disappointed in Anker for this. I will be returning the new product I bought."

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'And while the Bluetooth range on this speaker states 66 ft., I’ve been able to successfully connect the speaker via Bluetooth to my iPhone at a range of 80 ft. with no issues at all whatsoever.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that he was able to connect the speaker via Bluetooth to his iPhone at a range of 80 ft. with no issues at all whatsoever, even though the Bluetooth range on the speaker states 66 ft.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: I bought this speaker to use while hanging out outdoors on my back patio and in my backyard.  I wanted something that was waterproof and that had decent, good sound.  Well, this little powerhouse DEFINITELY checks those boxes!  While I haven’t immersed the speaker completely in water (like in a pool), it did survive, and continue to perform flawlessly, while directly under a constant stream (or gush) of water from my garden hose (when I was testing it’s water readiness right after I got it), and it’s survived more downpours of rain than I can count.  And the sound on it is great!  The sound is clear and can be loud (if you want it to be), even when playing bass heavy songs.  The battery life on it is also great!  I use/play it A LOT over the spring, summer, and fall seasons, including for long periods of time each time I use it, and I’ve only had to charge it a few times.  I’ve never had problems connecting the speaker via Bluetooth to my cell phone iPhone, nor either of my laptops Windows & a Mac.  And while the Bluetooth range on this speaker states 66 ft., I’ve been able to successfully connect the speaker via Bluetooth to my iPhone at a range of 80 ft. with no issues at all whatsoever.  After having this speaker for a few months and absolutely loving it, and wanting a similar speaker to keep in my garage for when I am doing stuff out in my garage and in my front yard, I didn’t even think twice about getting another Anker branded speaker.  I decided to “live life on the edge (LOL),” and so I decided to get a different model of Anker speaker, a “fancier” speaker, with more features, etc., and so of course this Anker speaker was a little more expensive than this Soundcore 2 speaker, and whoa!  Boy, how I regret that choice of mine getting another model of Anker Bluetooth speaker, an Anker speaker OTHER THAN this one, other than this Soundcore 2!  That other Anker portable Bluetooth speaker, the Flare 2 model, is HORRIBLE!  It’s absolute junk!, Even though that model of speaker Anker Flare 2 has more features than this speaker Anker Soundcore, and thus costs more than this more than this Soundcore, it can’t even perform the most basic of functions (doesn’t stay connected to Bluetooth source, no battery life, etc.), let alone perform the most basic of speaker functions (ie. has a decent quality sound) well!  I even had the Flare 2 speaker replaced by Anker under it’s manufacturer’s warranty, and I still had the exact same issues (minus the Bluetooth connectivity issue) with the replacement speaker that I received as I did with the original Anker Flare 2 speaker that I purchased!, So if you’re deciding between this Anker speaker, the Soundcore, and another similar Anker speaker (say the Anker Flare 2 speaker), I think that you’d be pleasantly surprised and pleased with the Anker Soundcore speaker, just like I was, and that you won’t regret your choice.

Review text: 1 week report:, I bought the Anker Soundcore2 as part of my back-to-school office as I am starting grad school. I had done some online research as I knew this what I would be rolling with for the next 5 years and was exhausting my gear budget. I\ve had this thing for a week now writing essays, browsing the internet, making ppt presentations, watching youtube etc. I am very pleased with it. (Full setup: LG gram 17, Philips 27" monitor, Jellycomb wireless keyboard+mouse, Anker Soundcore2 BT speakers, Saiji folding laptop stand.), 1. Sound quality: The audio fidelity is not bad, could be better. It has a lot of bass but the mids and highs, while not being super clear, are not mushed or cut off. The sound stage is small and condensed. The compact size with powerful drivers gives it a loud sound when physically close but the volume quickly diminishes at a distance. Sound will fill a small room but not in a pleasant, incognito way. The only reason this is forgiven is because of the compact size and the relatively inexpensive price., 2. Portability: Very small and portable size. Easy to carry around room to room and outside. It does have a hefty weight to it which both can be both a pro and con., 3. Connectivity: Connection does not fail in even when in the bedroom bathroom with the BT source in our living room going through 5 walls, furniture, a closet etc. It auto reconnects to the last device you had it connected to when turning it on and when changing the connection it to anything else it takes a few seconds. Pairing to a completely new device takes a little longer., 4. Build quality: Seems very sturdy with the rubber/plastic covering it from damage. The design is very under the radar in the black color. Buttons are near invisible in a darker room. Rubber flap covering the charge and AUX ports is unconvincing., 5. Battery life: Seems to be OK. Had it die a few times after listening to things almost all day. Would not last a full field trip with-out recharge but a good 10 hours seems to be reliable battery life., "6. You will want to get a firmware update from the Anker website and it will change the BT profile so you will have to forget and re-pair to devices that were previously paired. Also note that the Anker Soundcore app does not support this speaker (yet) so you cant use that to control the speaker with your phone."

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'Bluetooth pairing is extremely easy and it works great', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the Bluetooth pairing is extremely easy and it works great', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: This is a review for the X8 model. As the title says, it’s a really fine speaker system. I do have some quibbles with it, but I have used many other Bluetooth speaker systems and in terms of the X8 versus them, It’s the best one I’ve tried. The volume is quite good, the stereo separation is surprisingly good for a single unit. I have not tried pairing it with a second unit., What makes the X8 stand out for me is the EQ button, which almost no other Bluetooth speaker has. Many of them claim to have deep bass, but being an audio engineer, I know but not all music sources are the same. For instance watching television is a relatively mid range sound source. Listening to YouTube videos is a very different animal.  And gaming and watching movies is a third. The default setting when you turn it on is appropriate for watching television and many audio sources. It’s the most balanced sound with good bass and and smooth even mid range. It works for classical music sources, and jazz, as well as oldies Pop music.  If you switch to the second setting, You get enhanced mid range, so that works for spoken word meaning podcasts, and any spoken audio. Even some music sources benefit from the enhanced mid range., The third setting has very strong base, better than I’ve heard in any other speaker that I’ve tried. There are two passive subwoofer ports on either end, which are completely waterproof, So bring it to the pool, submerge it in the pool, use it at the beach etc. and you have nothing to worry about & as I say, the sound pressure for deep bass is crisp and handles hip-hop music, rock music and any source that has strong base. The base is crystal clear, which I have not found in any other unit, they usually have a muffled bass sound which is pretty awful.,  Obviously any sound source you’re using, may benefit from any one of the three settings, and that’s what sets this apart from any other unit. That is also why most of the units fail to deliver. Every sound source is different and the X8 gives you the opportunity to adjust to any type of sound quality. I had originally purchased the X10 from the same company which is smaller and roughly half the wattage, and even though it has the passive drivers, it just isn’t loud enough or powerful enough, so I returned it to get this 40 want unit. Also the two speakers are side by side in the round cylinder so you actually get a very true stereo quality. All the other units I’ve tried don’t actually sound like their stereo, they probably work with the pairing of another unit, but these are all called stereo, and I want the single unit to sound like a stereo., I should note that the buttons, while they feel positively military grade and I assume will last practically forever, they are hard to press, so if you have imited strength in your hands you may find it difficult to press any of the buttons, they are quite stiff. However I have read reviews of brother units that all say the buttons fail after a short period of time so I’m willing to deal with a bit of extra effort to work the buttons on the X8. Bluetooth pairing is extremely easy and it works great. As to the battery life, all these companies just lie. There isn’t anyway on this planet that this unit gives you 30 hours of audio. It lasts for a good session of a couple of hours, an afternoon at the pool but it will need recharging after that. No I have a unit at this price point with this much power, will last any longer than the 2600 Milla amp battery X8 has. 40 wants requires a significant amount of power, and that’s that . You can’t change the laws of physics, and they’d have to put a huge battery in it for it to actually last 30 hours. I can’t review the telephone functionality , because I don’t use it and I wouldn’t. Because the X8 has so many different functions, many of the functions use the same buttons as the basic volume, EQ, & on off functions,  but there are double presses, long hold presses, and to me that’s just confusing, but there’s just a limited number of buttons so each one has multiple jobs., Strangely, The manual that I got with this unit which was brand new and sealed and obviously not repackaged, has instructions are completely wrong. They are in fact the instructions that work for the X10, Because I had the X 10 and I know how the buttons work on that.There are buttons labeled nine 1011 and 12, that don’t exist on this. Having had the X10, I know that the instructions actually match the X10 not this X8. That said, with a bit of playing around I figured out the correct buttons to use. you may be able to contact the company, and get a set of the correct instructions.  The basic functions work perfectly fine : Power on power off, EQ button, volume up volume down, etc. These units, coming from China always seem to have a problem with the instructions. but the bottom line is you want good sound and you want the ability to adjust the EQ for different ways you want to use the speaker, that’s why I’m keeping this, and I really like it, because it does what a 40 watt speaker is supposed to do., All in one I’m giving it four stars because it’s an extremely well built unit and feels very solid, has very good volume, superior  bass and the ability to adjust the sound, which as I say, is way better than any other at this price point. I consider it an excellent value for the money. I highly recommend it.

QA_Content: The user mentioned that the Bluetooth pairing is extremely easy and it works great

Review text:
The speaker looks nice, but disappointed with the battery life.

I got it to play in my garage while working.

I played it at a moderate volume, with the lights OFF and got about 17 hours of play time.

And there’s no way it would connect at up to 66 feet away…more like about 30 feet, 40, if I was lucky…beyond that range, it started crackling pretty bad.

There were no “reminders” to recharge the battery, it just quit.

The buttons have way too many functions.

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'sound quality of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'The sound quality is ok. It sounded fine on its default EQ mode, and it didnt really distort at the highest volume level. It didnt sound particularly weak or tinny, but it didnt have much bass.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the sound quality is okay. It sounded fine on its default EQ mode and did not distort at the highest volume level. However, it did not have much bass.', 'sentiment': 'neutral'}"
Review text: "Without bothering to look at any instructions, it quickly paired with my Samsung S23 Ultra. Although my phone initially identified it as headphones, so I had to change it to identify it as a speaker. It had a mostly full charge out of the box, with its own led indicator showing that it was near full as it was flashing upon my plugging it in. My phone reported its charge level as already being at 100%, but the led was still flashing to indicate that it was still accepting a charge, so I left it plugged in until it eventually stopped flashing.", "The sound quality is ok. It sounded fine on its default EQ mode, and it didnt really distort at the highest volume level. It didnt sound particularly weak or tinny, but it didnt have much bass. Both of the other EQ modes sound ok too, although the Base boost mode did start to sound distorted at higher volume levels. The base hits in that mode do hit harder and deeper, but they also sound restrained, and it sounds like maybe theres a point at which a crossover prevents damage to the speaker by holding back on me. The overall volume level doesnt really seem to get very loud, either. Just lots enough for a fairly big room, and Im sure it will suffice for sitting around a campfire.", "The perfectly round shape might become pretty annoying when I just want to lay the speaker on its side. I wish they had built in a couple of hinged flaps that could be swung out for the purpose of preventing it from just rolling right off of a flat surface like a table. Just little solid tabs that could pop out and stay extended in place by magnetic force or something, and then be retracted back flush into the side of the speaker when not needed. Although at least theres a nice, thick rubber strap on a swivel at the top for carrying or hanging, and it seems like it might be just enough to prevent the speaker from rolling away as long as you position the strap in just the right way when you lay the speaker on its side.", Of course you can always just stand the speaker up vertically, but with a bass radiator on each end the one on the bottom might cause undue rattling of any stuff on that table, especially at higher volumes., I need to see how long it will last during my upcoming camping trip, and I think 10 hours of battery life at a volume around halfway to three-quarters would be ok for me. 30 hours seems like something you could maybe get at a really low volume and with the cool lights turned off.  I think it takes maybe 5 hours to fully charge, and that's fine for me. That means the internal batteries don't get really hot by cramming a bunch of energy into them really fast. So you'll likely get years of reliable use before the batteries ever start to crap out on you. Beware of any Bluetooth speaker that claims to have "sick, lit, extreme fast charging* or whatever, because it's internal batteries probably will start letting you down within a year if you use it frequently., "And this thing is built like a tank. If I accidentally drop it off a rocky cliff, theres a fair chance that it will survive. As long as it doesnt land directly on either vertical end on a point, since the bass radiator in each end is exposed and has no casing over it.", "The buttons definitely feel like military-grade or something. They are bizarrely hard to press. Just hold an actual rock in your hand, and start squeezing that rock. Pretend that the solid rock has imaginary buttons recessed into its side. Pretend that you are trying to push those buttons inward with your fingertips. Thats how hard it is to push these buttons on the side of this speaker. Drop this thing into the North Atlantic so it sinks down next to the Titanic, and the extremely intense water pressure down there might not even faze these buttons.", "For a comparison of the sound quality, I think its pretty similar to my old Bluetooth speaker that was shaped like a lone triangle. The angular one. And I really liked that one back in the day, so thats saying something. Compared to Echo smart speakers, it sounds much, much better than my Echo Dot (4tj Gen), but not as good or as loud as my regular Echo (4th Gen). For the money, Im happy to go with this instead of blowing much more money on another brand that probably doesnt even sound much better than this. If it turns out that I get Herculean battery life during my camping trip next week, I might update my rating from 4 to 5 stars."

Review text: This is a review for the X8 model. As the title says, it’s a really fine speaker system. I do have some quibbles with it, but I have used many other Bluetooth speaker systems and in terms of the X8 versus them, It’s the best one I’ve tried. The volume is quite good, the stereo separation is surprisingly good for a single unit. I have not tried pairing it with a second unit., What makes the X8 stand out for me is the EQ button, which almost no other Bluetooth speaker has. Many of them claim to have deep bass, but being an audio engineer, I know but not all music sources are the same. For instance watching television is a relatively mid range sound source. Listening to YouTube videos is a very different animal.  And gaming and watching movies is a third. The default setting when you turn it on is appropriate for watching television and many audio sources. It’s the most balanced sound with good bass and and smooth even mid range. It works for classical music sources, and jazz, as well as oldies Pop music.  If you switch to the second setting, You get enhanced mid range, so that works for spoken word meaning podcasts, and any spoken audio. Even some music sources benefit from the enhanced mid range., The third setting has very strong base, better than I’ve heard in any other speaker that I’ve tried. There are two passive subwoofer ports on either end, which are completely waterproof, So bring it to the pool, submerge it in the pool, use it at the beach etc. and you have nothing to worry about & as I say, the sound pressure for deep bass is crisp and handles hip-hop music, rock music and any source that has strong base. The base is crystal clear, which I have not found in any other unit, they usually have a muffled bass sound which is pretty awful.,  Obviously any sound source you’re using, may benefit from any one of the three settings, and that’s what sets this apart from any other unit. That is also why most of the units fail to deliver. Every sound source is different and the X8 gives you the opportunity to adjust to any type of sound quality. I had originally purchased the X10 from the same company which is smaller and roughly half the wattage, and even though it has the passive drivers, it just isn’t loud enough or powerful enough, so I returned it to get this 40 want unit. Also the two speakers are side by side in the round cylinder so you actually get a very true stereo quality. All the other units I’ve tried don’t actually sound like their stereo, they probably work with the pairing of another unit, but these are all called stereo, and I want the single unit to sound like a stereo., I should note that the buttons, while they feel positively military grade and I assume will last practically forever, they are hard to press, so if you have imited strength in your hands you may find it difficult to press any of the buttons, they are quite stiff. However I have read reviews of brother units that all say the buttons fail after a short period of time so I’m willing to deal with a bit of extra effort to work the buttons on the X8. Bluetooth pairing is extremely easy and it works great. As to the battery life, all these companies just lie. There isn’t anyway on this planet that this unit gives you 30 hours of audio. It lasts for a good session of a couple of hours, an afternoon at the pool but it will need recharging after that. No I have a unit at this price point with this much power, will last any longer than the 2600 Milla amp battery X8 has. 40 wants requires a significant amount of power, and that’s that . You can’t change the laws of physics, and they’d have to put a huge battery in it for it to actually last 30 hours. I can’t review the telephone functionality , because I don’t use it and I wouldn’t. Because the X8 has so many different functions, many of the functions use the same buttons as the basic volume, EQ, & on off functions,  but there are double presses, long hold presses, and to me that’s just confusing, but there’s just a limited number of buttons so each one has multiple jobs., Strangely, The manual that I got with this unit which was brand new and sealed and obviously not repackaged, has instructions are completely wrong. They are in fact the instructions that work for the X10, Because I had the X 10 and I know how the buttons work on that.There are buttons labeled nine 1011 and 12, that don’t exist on this. Having had the X10, I know that the instructions actually match the X10 not this X8. That said, with a bit of playing around I figured out the correct buttons to use. you may be able to contact the company, and get a set of the correct instructions.  The basic functions work perfectly fine : Power on power off, EQ button, volume up volume down, etc. These units, coming from China always seem to have a problem with the instructions. but the bottom line is you want good sound and you want the ability to adjust the EQ for different ways you want to use the speaker, that’s why I’m keeping this, and I really like it, because it does what a 40 watt speaker is supposed to do., All in one I’m giving it four stars because it’s an extremely well built unit and feels very solid, has very good volume, superior  bass and the ability to adjust the sound, which as I say, is way better than any other at this price point. I consider it an excellent value for the money. I highly recommend it.

Review text: "Ive been using the Anker SoundCore daily for the past five months. I continue to be surprised by how good this tiny little speaker is.", "Sound Quality: Better than expected, especially considering that this thing fits in the palm of your hand! Obviously its not going to sound like a full size stereo system, but it sounds MUCH better than most other portable speakers of the same size, and it even sounds better than some portable speakers that are larger than the SoundCore.", One can obtain even better sound by experimenting with position/placement of the speaker. Try moving it around. Try aiming it in different directions or raising/lowering the height of it., "Ive used the SoundCore at home, in the bathroom, in the car, and outdoors. It works well in all of those scenarios.", "Battery Life: WAY better than expected! Ive been using this speaker for a minimum of 20 minutes a day, and sometimes up to two hours a day, for the past five months. Ive only recharged it twice — and the battery wasnt totally run down when I recharged it. The battery life is simply amazing.", Overall Quality: Excellent. It feels very solid and well made. The rubberized surface makes it very easy to grip and handle., I tested the speaker with four Bluetooth devices: an iPhone 5S running iOS 8; an iPod Touch running iOS 9; an iPhone 7 running iOS 10; and a five year old MacBook Pro. The SoundCore worked with all of them without any issues., "My only very minor complaint is that I wish it had a reverse button (to go back to the previous song). You can press the play button twice to skip ahead to the next song, but theres no way to go back to the previous song. I also wish that the buttons were a little bit easier to press. Other than those two minor issues, I think this is a truly great Bluetooth speaker for anyone who needs something very small but also wants very good sound and incredible battery life. Ill probably buy another one!", "UPDATE, November 2018: Ive now had this speaker for almost two years and it still performs just as well as the day I bought it. Battery life is unbelievable."

Review text: I got this speaker for use in my home office. I am in the process of slowly converting to being as much of a Smart Home as any renter can. Due to this, I am primarily buying devices that are compatible with either Alexa or Samsung SmartThings., When I saw this speaker come up in the Black Friday sales from Anker (sold by Anker Direct, as this is their only web store that they use) I did a quick glance over the Q&A and saw that it should be Alexa compatible. Once I got and charged it, I put it to a quick test for sound quality. I can honestly say that just like every other Anker product I have ever owned, the quality is amazing., Today, I decided to connect it to Alexa. To do this, I un-paired it with my phone to make sure that there are no conflicts and went through the normal steps.... and nothing. It sat in paring mode, and the Alexa app sat searching, for 10 minutes and the app still did not see it. As this product provides Amazon support for a little while I opened up a chat and asked for help. 3 people and 20 minutes later and I am told that it is not compatible with Alexa and I would have to use an Aux cord to connect it to an Echo for it to act as the speaker., The only reason that I did not contact Anker support is that they do not open until 9AM Pacific USA time, and it was 9:30 AM Eastern time.

Review text: This is a fairly small product. The volume-level is excellent for my purposes, I use it on an electric pallet lift while stocking a 16,000 sqft store. The controls are good and the battery life so far for me has been excellent. I\ve had no issues with the connectivity. There is a app for this device and the app is pretty useless unless you have these units in multiples for stereo pairing, etc. The bass-level is about appropriate for this device\s size, one might want more bass, but bass is a function of size, and there\s no way to get the levels that a 12" subwoofer can attain in a package of this size. Note that my photo shows the device in an aftermarket case.

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'compatibility of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'Pairing with my iPhone XR was quick and smooth and auto connects easily to my phone when powered on.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that pairing with iPhone XR was quick and smooth and auto connects easily to his phone when powered on.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text:
The ION Clip is more compact but definitely is no match for the JBL 4., The clip can double as a handle and the raised controls are easy to use.  

Pairing with my iPhone XR was quick and smooth and auto connects easily to my phone when powered on.  

I played a movie and there was no lag with the voices.

, The price could be at least $10 less  but using an Amazon gift card reduced the cost.

I purchased the black because the gray that I really wanted was $10 more.

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'compatibility of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'The USB Type-C port does not have a dust cover; another omission from the Clip 3s design.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the USB Type-C port of the speaker does not have a dust cover and it is an omission from the Clip 3s design.', 'sentiment': 'negative'}"
Review text: "The vast majority of the reviews I read before buying this led me to believe that the sound quality was so similar to the Clip 3 that it wasnt worth upgrading. My Clip 3 has been a great speaker—Ill probably keep finding uses for it until it wont hold a charge anymore, hopefully not anytime soon—but honestly...I really wanted to upgrade because its one of the last devices I own with a Micro USB connector for charging.", "Anyways, the Clip 4 has turned out to be a noticeably better speaker. Reading over JBLs own writings about the Clip 3 and 4, it seems like version 4 incorporates a passive radiator (like their larger portable speakers), which explains the much improved bass and low-midrange clarity. It wont fool anyone at high volumes, but for low volume playback in a quiet space—which is what I always used my Clip 3 for anyways—it does manage to sound a bit larger than its size suggests it should.", "My Clip 3 is a noisy speaker; with no audio playing, theres always some low-level hissing thats clearly audible if its close enough to the ear. It also seems to impart a barely perceptible crunchy distortion onto everything I play through it. The Clip 4, on the other hand, is dead silent when nothing is playing, and doesnt have that gritty veil of distortion over the upper-mids and treble frequencies; possibly a side effect of the 3.5mm TRS input being removed.", The titular clip on version 4 has a slightly wider opening, and the larger space inside the clip makes it easier to maneuver onto some things I couldn't get the Clip 3's carabiner over. At the narrowest point, the Clip 4's opening measures about 5/8" wide, only slightly larger than the Clip 3's 9/16" opening., Now for the downsides:, "The Clip 4s power and pairing buttons are much easier to press (i.e., accidentally) than the recessed buttons on the side of the Clip 3. Not a huge issue if its sitting or hanging somewhere solid and stationary, but I could imagine that it might turn itself on/off or go into pairing mode if its swinging around on a backpack or something. I put mine into pairing mode by mistake twice while handling it to measure the carabiner opening.", Of course, I have to mention the loss of the analog input. I admit that I rarely ever use(d) it on the Clip 3, but it was indispensable when I needed it in a pinch., "The USB Type-C port does not have a dust cover; another omission from the Clip 3s design. I never cared for it, but its worth mentioning if you use yours in dusty or wet environments. Maybe not a huge issue, since the Clip 4 carries an IP67 rating.", "Finally, the carabiner clip just doesnt feel as sturdy. Version 4 appears to use some kind of plastic hinge, where the Clip 3s was made of anodized aluminum like the rest of the hook. It may well hold up for years just like the previous version, but only time will tell.", "Overall, The Clip 4 is a respectable step-up in sound quality, with a few odd design changes from version 3 that may or may not make it less reliable, depending on how you intend to use it. For my use case—quietly listening to music and podcasts in bed, or during power outages when I cant use my hi-fi—it fits the bill perfectly so far.", Oh, and one last thing: this "Grey" color scheme is properly weird. The aluminum parts are a kind of golden orange, the plastic clip and button accents are what I can only describe as "puce," and the JBL logo is some kind of desaturated teal color. It looks so strange that it's almost bad, but I love it.

QA_Content: The user mentioned that the USB Type-C port of the speaker does not have a dust cover and it is an omission from the Clip 3s design.
Processed_QA_Content: The USB Type-C port of the speaker lacks a dust cover, which is an omission from the Clip 3s design.

Review text:
My original transmitter had Bluetooth 4.2.

This speaker requires BT5.1.

I found BT5.0, while close, does not work.

And BT5.1 transmitters are somewhat difficult to find for use in the configuration I was using a transmitter.

But after finding such a transmitter, I was able to connect the Clip 4 and I couldnt be happier.

Great little speaker.

Great sound for such a small package!

It appears it is designed to take the rough and tumble of using it out doors as I will.

Thanks JBL!"

Has really good sound up close (almost too loud at max volume), and maintained a good bluetooth connection.  

But sound dies more than 10 yards away outdoors.  

You can hear that something is playing, but really cant make it out.

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'battery life of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'Battery life is rated at 6 hours, but anecdotally it seems to last longer than that', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the battery life is rated at 6 hours but anecdotally it seems to last longer than that.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: "Full transparency - Im a huge Bose fan.  It wasnt until later in life that I was able to afford their products, but now given the choice I prefer to go with Bose.  This little speaker is just the latest in my history of Bose products.", I had an older Bose Sound Link Mini  that worked well but was starting to show its age.  It was also a bit clunky and very, very delicate.  I was perusing Amazon and came across this little gem and bought one for my wife.  She was so impressed with hers that I bought one for me., What I like - well, obviously, it\s Bose.  The sound is crisp and rich in replicating lows and highs and is characteristic Bose.  Obviously bass is somewhat less than other speakers, but for this size speaker the sound is incredible and I\m not a huge fan of "thumpy" bass anyway.  I also like the portability.  I used the strap to attach the speaker to my belt while doing my evening walk at work and loved that I was able to listen to my MP3 player without having to worry about headphones and potentially getting hit by some of the maintenance vehicles in the factory.  I like the Bose app that indicates remaining battery life and bluetooth connections.  I\m sure I\m only scratching the surface with the available features, but for what I use it for I\m extremely pleased., "As awesome as this little gem is, not all is perfect.  There are some issues with the speaker wanting to connect to everything in sight.  I love that you can connect to two gadgets simultaneously, but sometimes I dont want that feature and only want one.  It takes a little doing but it can connect to just the one, but its not intuitive.  Not a deal breaker.  Also there is no feature to plug in an analog MP3 player or device, but since Im using the bluetooth capability as my excuse to the Mrs. for upgrading my portable capability that really is a non-issue.", "Ive only had the speaker a very short time, but already love it.  At some point I would like to test the stereo feature when you connect two speakers to one device, but at the moment my wife and I love having our own discrete speakers.  Battery life is rated at 6 hours, but anecdotally it seems to last longer than that.  I also dont blast my music at loud volume, so Im not certain if theres a correlation there.  I may have to update my review at a later date after I collect more data and get more enjoyment from the speaker.", "In summary, the buyer should know that this is what it is...a small, portable and extremely capable Bose speaker.  If youre looking for incredibly high highs and rap lows, this may not fill your bill.  But if you like your music on the go and with pleasant sound, this is your recommended default."

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'The Flip 6 I think has slightly better range than the Xtreme 2, but it isnt as powerful sounding.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the Flip 6 has slightly better range than the Xtreme 2, but it is not as powerful sounding.', 'sentiment': 'neutral'}"
Review text: "I wanted to review three JBL speakers, comparatively, in one go.  I have in front of me now the Flip 6, Xtreme 2 and Xtreme 3.  I started with the Flip 6, to replace some aging Bose soundlink Micros (Flip 6 is way better than both Bose Micro and Flex, IMO).  Overall, of the three the Flip 6 is the best bang for the buck...great range of sound, decent volume and bass for indoor use.  Does distort a little at max volume.  I then got the Xtreme 3 with high hopes.  It has tremendously crisp highs, deep lows, but it is VERY lacking in the midrange...the sound feels hollow, empty.  Might be OK for synthetic music, but for anything instrumental I was disappointed.  What I did find is if you pair the Flip 6 with the Xtreme 3 in party mode, they together sound very good.  The Flip 6 fills the holes in the sound of the Xtreme 3, the Xtreme 3 expands the sound of the Flip 6.  A great pairing...but now you need two speakers.  So then I got the Xtreme 2...which I will be keeping instead of the Xtreme 3.  The treble isnt as crisp, the base maybe not quite as low, but it has good midrange, a much more balanced sound.  A good way to explain it might be that the Xtreme 3 is better for drums/beats but the Xtreme 2 is better for bass and rhythm guitar.  I wish that the Xtreme 2 could do party mode with the Flip 6, I bet that would be awesome, but the Xtreme 2 doesnt pair with the newer ones.  The Flip 6 I think has slightly better range than the Xtreme 2, but it isnt as powerful sounding.  Xtreme 2 gets louder and doesnt seem to distort at high volume.  In conclusion, from my perspective:  the Flip 6 is the better overall, bang for the buck, for indoor use.  The Xtreme 2 is really good, would take if over the Flip 6 for outdoors and wouldnt be sad to have it in the house.  The Xtreme 3 alone is just plain lacking...but if used in conjunction with the Flip 6,together are quite good.  Xtreme 3 plus Flip 6 is louder and crisper than Xtreme 2 alone, a bit better range but not as powerful of a tone and still not as balanced in the mids."

QA_Content: The user mentioned that the Flip 6 has slightly better range than the Xtreme 2, but it is not as powerful sounding.
Processed_QA_Content: The Flip 6 has a slightly better range than the Xtreme 2, but it is not as powerful sounding.

I think the Charge 5 is superior, worth lugging the extra size/weight for decent sound. The Charge 5 is much less of a sound compromise and actually has bass. Also, I feel like this is overpriced, even on sale. Something like this should be $80."

Review text: I hate this speaker soo much that I lost it and I\m happy I lost it because every time I would see it, it would remind me on how much I hate it. Have you ever not put enough sugar in your Kool-Aid? Can you imagine that taste? Imagine the sugar is the volume and the Kool-Aid is the speaker.  This speakers high volume is other speakers medium volume. I could have this all the way turned up in my work truck and have a conversation with the passenger without raising my voice. I figured "it\s splash proof. I\ll use it in the shower." NO, NO, can barely hear it over the noise of the shower. If you were listening to a song you knew in the shower you\d be able to keep up with the song.  But if you\re listening to something like an audio book, yeah, that\s not gonna happen. I wanted to return it but I didn\t because it technically worked. OK look, just to show you I\m not biased I will say something nice about this speaker. I have never owned a Bluetooth device that had this level of connectivity, it was phenomenal. I would leave this speaker in my truck go inside the corner store and the speaker stay connected. The only downside is, what\s the point of having 100ft connectivity, IF YOU CAN BARELY HEAR THE GD SPEAKER? OOHHH MY GOODNESS I hate this speaker soo much. There\s no tone to notify you if your volume is all the way up. There was something else about this speaker that I didn\t like, I was gonna use it again before I wrote this review to make the review more accurate but like I said I lost it. Good riddance.

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'portability of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'Portability - its smaller than you would believe for the sound it puts out.
