Review text: "  Whether you like to listen to Mozart or Nirvana, and you need a small, portable speaker, the OontZ Angle 3 Ultra will come through with flying colors. Heres what I like best about it.", 1) Great sound - in a small room, it really shines. Use it while showering, in the office, reading, or just relaxing with friends. Place it on a hard flat surface or in a walled corner for maximum bass., 2) Excellent battery life - seems like it goes forever without running out of juice. I charge it fairly often, and I have not taken it places where there is no power outlets. But I have had it run for hours with no sign of losing juice., "3) Portability - its smaller than you would believe for the sound it puts out. Easily stows away in a backpack or bag. While the battery if substantial, the weight does not feel like it is a burden if you are carrying it. Its also easily stashed out if the way, so people may not even realize the amazing sound is coming from such a small speaker. Works great in a golf cart, but you could anger other golfers if you turn it up too high. Fine for private golf outings where it is more of a fun round among friends and colleagues.", 4) Sturdy - the rubberized case helps minimize impact damage if dropped. The water resistance is also a big plus if it starts to rain. I would not drop it in a pool, but it is supposed to be able to withstand a plunge in the water., 5) Price $49? Seriously? This is an amazing deal. They really knocked it out of the park on value., Cons, 1) Not an elite speaker for outdoors. You lose some bass if you cannot set this on a hard surface, or against a wall. Still very good sound, but outside it may seem a bit under powered if you are looking to fill up the air when swimming, grilling, or chilling. But it is fine on your grill station if it is just you or a couple people around the grill or at the table., 2) No case. I would like to have a case with a mesh cover, so the speaker can be hung up (while camping, hiking, or biking). A trip to a discount store will fix that., 3) It makes me want to buy another one to pair it for stereo sound and more area-filling sound. It also gets me excited about the even more potent OontZ Angle 3XL ULTRA, a portable bluetooth speaker which which can fill up a patio, picnic gathering, sports field, or other outdoor area.

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'portability of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'I bought this speaker to use as a living room speakers, as many reviews suggested they would work great for this purpose. And though I agree some people would be satisfied with the sound of these for their living room, I found the sound to be too flat, too little bass, and not room filling enough to be used as living room speakers.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that he bought this speaker to use as a living room speaker, but he found the sound to be too flat, too little bass, and not room filling enough to be used as living room speakers.', 'sentiment': 'negative'}"
Review text: "  Ive always been a big fan of Cambridge SoundWorks speakers, so it was a no-brainer to buy these, especially with all the great reviews. I would rate these as a good, low cost, portable speaker, but I would not rave about their exceptional sound quality. I played them side-by-side with other bluetooth speakers with a similar size and price point, such as the Anker Soundcore 2, JamBox, Solemake, ect. The sound quality slightly edged out a couple, but otherwise it was very close, or slightly below. Thats not to say they are bad by any means. They are great for the size and price, but I wouldnt buy these if you seek high quality sound over portability. The sound is pretty flat and the bass isnt very strong unless you are sitting very close to them. Usually a good bass radiator can produce pretty remarkable, room filling bass from very small speakers, but that wasnt the case with these.", I bought this speaker to use as a living room speakers, as many reviews suggested they would work great for this purpose. And though I agree some people would be satisfied with the sound of these for their living room, I found the sound to be too flat, too little bass, and not room filling enough to be used as living room speakers. The sound distorts before they are able to get to the volume that would be suitable if you were having guests over too. But as a close range speaker for a small room these will do the trick.

Review text: So close to 5 stars!, I am upgrading/updating from a JBL Flip 4, which is still one of my favorites. I like the portability and the crisper sound that the Flip 4 offers relative to the Flip 5 or the Charge series. The Flip 4 comes with two drivers and can purportedly produce stereo sound on its own. Keep in mind that the stereo separation is dictated by how far the L and R channels are to each other, which is pretty much limited to within the size of the Flip 4 (not very much)., "But this is about the Flip 6.  The first thing I noticed is that the Flip 6 pushed out more sound, its louder. It still has the clear highs (even if they are a bit harsh) but it produces a fuller, more dynamic sound, especially for the lower frequencies. So the basslines sound a lot more powerful for rock tracks on the 6 than on the 4. The 6 does not play stereo on its own, but the specs indicate that one can use two Flip 6 units via the JBL app to create a stereo pair (each speaker playing the L and the R channel, respectively) or to create a daily chain (2+ speakers playing the exact same sound, without L and R separation). I have not tried this feature, but even a Flip 6 solo sounds pretty good. Im using it for casual listening/background music indoors and outdoors.", "The 6 has a 4800mAh battery compared to the 3000mAh on the 4.  The 6 is also rated IPX67 and its supposedly waterproof/submersible (for up to 30 minutes) and dustproof. The 4 is rated IPX7 which is only waterproof/submersible, but not dustproof. Curiously though, the 6 has the USB-C charging port exposed. The 4 has a USB-A port and an aux port, and both of them are covered behind a weatherproof flap. Despite the dustproof rating on the 6, I may have to put a piece of tape over the port to help prevent sand from getting into the port when I take it to the beach. Yeah, thats where the -1 star comes from. My unit also crackles a bit from time to time. It doesnt appear to be an internal wiring/connection issue. It could be a bluetooth issue. Either way, it interrupts the sonic experience and gives me concern about the quality, reliability, and longevity of the 6 vs my old trusted 4."

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'The Flip 6 I think has slightly better range than the Xtreme 2, but it isnt as powerful sounding. Xtreme 2 gets louder and doesnt seem to distort at high volume.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the Flip 6 has slightly better range than the Xtreme 2, but it is not as powerful sounding. He also mentioned that the Xtreme 2 gets louder and does not distort at high volume.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: "I wanted to review three JBL speakers, comparatively, in one go.  I have in front of me now the Flip 6, Xtreme 2 and Xtreme 3.  I started with the Flip 6, to replace some aging Bose soundlink Micros (Flip 6 is way better than both Bose Micro and Flex, IMO).  Overall, of the three the Flip 6 is the best bang for the buck...great range of sound, decent volume and bass for indoor use.  Does distort a little at max volume.  I then got the Xtreme 3 with high hopes.  It has tremendously crisp highs, deep lows, but it is VERY lacking in the midrange...the sound feels hollow, empty.  Might be OK for synthetic music, but for anything instrumental I was disappointed.  What I did find is if you pair the Flip 6 with the Xtreme 3 in party mode, they together sound very good.  The Flip 6 fills the holes in the sound of the Xtreme 3, the Xtreme 3 expands the sound of the Flip 6.  A great pairing...but now you need two speakers.  So then I got the Xtreme 2...which I will be keeping instead of the Xtreme 3.  The treble isnt as crisp, the base maybe not quite as low, but it has good midrange, a much more balanced sound.  A good way to explain it might be that the Xtreme 3 is better for drums/beats but the Xtreme 2 is better for bass and rhythm guitar.  I wish that the Xtreme 2 could do party mode with the Flip 6, I bet that would be awesome, but the Xtreme 2 doesnt pair with the newer ones.  The Flip 6 I think has slightly better range than the Xtreme 2, but it isnt as powerful sounding.  Xtreme 2 gets louder and doesnt seem to distort at high volume.  In conclusion, from my perspective:  the Flip 6 is the better overall, bang for the buck, for indoor use.  The Xtreme 2 is really good, would take if over the Flip 6 for outdoors and wouldnt be sad to have it in the house.  The Xtreme 3 alone is just plain lacking...but if used in conjunction with the Flip 6,together are quite good.  Xtreme 3 plus Flip 6 is louder and crisper than Xtreme 2 alone, a bit better range but not as powerful of a tone and still not as balanced in the mids."

He also mentioned that the Xtreme 2 gets louder and does not distort at high volume.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}
QA_Content: The user mentioned that the Flip 6 has slightly better range than the Xtreme 2, but it is not as powerful sounding. He also mentioned that the Xtreme 2 gets louder and does not distort at high volume.
Processed_QA_Content: The Flip 6 has slightly better range than the Xtreme 2, but the Xtreme 2 gets louder and does not distort at high volume.

Curiously though, the 6 has the USB-C charging port exposed.

The 4 has a USB-A port and an aux port, and both of them are covered behind a weatherproof flap.

Despite the dustproof rating on the 6, I may have to put a piece of tape over the port to help prevent sand from getting into the port when I take it to the beach.

Yeah, thats where the -1 star comes from.

My unit also crackles a bit from time to time.

Review text: "Its a great product. But dont be fooled, this is still a compromise of a speaker. To me it is pretty high, too high. Even when tweaking EQ. I just think some of the reviews oversell this thing. This is a small speaker that sounds small. Dont expect real full bass, its a backpack speaker. Its decent for pop and some basic lowkey music, but rock/metal or anything that needs a good mid - sounds terrible. This is a compromise for portability. Its great if you have nothing else. Its decent if you have 2-4 people chilling out and about and want some lowkey background music, but I wouldnt use this to host a 10 person backyard party at all. I think the Charge 5 is superior, worth lugging the extra size/weight for decent sound. The Charge 5 is much less of a sound compromise and actually has bass. Also, I feel like this is overpriced, even on sale. Something like this should be $80."

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'I wanted to tell you this one has a very good range and response for a 14 dollar unit. Review text: "  Hey fellow Amazon shoppers. I rarely write a review here, but a couple of times I have when I come across a product that TRULY is worth the cost. This speaker is just such an example. Ive owned it for only two days, and am thrilled with its performance. I paid $14.44 total (With free Prime Shipping). I am a music nut and a musician and amateur sound engineer myself. I want to ENJOY my off nights with wine and rock roll. I listen to pretty highly produced stuff like Meat Loaf, Alan Parsons Project, Dream Theater, King Crimson, Pink Floyd etc.  I have owned maybe a dozen bluetooth speakers ranging from the cheapest $10 one I could find at Wal Mart, to $50 ones from Ebay or Amazon. I wont spend more than that on a portable wireless speaker - rather invest in a pricey and exceptional home stereo system. Alas, I find myself living alone in a one bedroom apartment. A bluetooth speaker is really all I can jam at full capacity. I wanted to tell you this one has a very good range and response for a 14 dollar unit. At 100% volume - Unless the recording is very loud - There is no distortion. The battery lasts a long time, and you can even get enough natural sounding bass - not overdoing it to where muddiness or distortion occurs. As a very serious customer of the wireless speaker - I must recommend it! I hope it does not crap out on me in just a few months like several already have. But my first impression is a good one! Loud, clear, and pretty darn cheap!"

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'portability of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'Add the portability and you have one handy device. Review text: "  This product is extremely easy to use. You unwind the USB cord and plug it into a port on your computer. On Windows 7, the drivers installed automatically and Skype configured the device without me tweaking a single setting. I just plugged it in and everything worked, instantly. I didnt even need to install the Jabra Suite.", "What impressed me the most was how powerful the speaker is. Usually, devices powered through the USB port tend to be a little weak/slow--thats where a USB connection coupled with an AC adapter come in. But with the Jabra SPEAK410, the USB power is more than enough. Not only is the speaker loud enough for everyone to hear in a large room, but it picks up the voices of those talking to it and delivers them at a high volume. Its even good at picking up people who talk quietly or who are further away.", A group of people can easily sit at a conference room table and carry on a clear conversation with those on the other end. Add the portability and you have one handy device. Perfect for sales people, traveling from place to place with a laptop. The package also comes with a zippable, carrying case that fits easily into a laptop bag., "Theres only one cable, which nicely winds around the speaker for easy storage--its not as messy to carry around as other devices with removable cables such as smartphones and tablets. The buttons for controlling the volume, mute, answer/on, and end/off are flesh activated. Meaning, it senses the heat of your finger when you press it. Theres no moving parts to the buttons that would wear off or fall out with extensive usage.", Not only do I find this a good business solution for on the road, but it works perfectly for connecting with gaming buddies or talking to family over video calling. It works much better than the mic and speaker system built into my laptop., If you give this a shot, I think you will be pleased.

And mute.

I never thought of this before, and I review a lot of rechargeable devices, but there are better grades of rechargeable batteries out there.  I would assume they are more expensive, and the text details this has a battery made for an electric vehicle and it will recharge more than three times the number of many rechargeable batteries.  I know that problem well as some cordless phones Ive had since 2012 keep dying with little charge, and Ive had to replace batteries on most of the phones.  The tech I didnt consider is because obviously an electric car, golf cart, or one of those grocery store mobilities, are charged almost every day.  It would be bad if they only lasted a year because the battery packs are likely very expensive. I tried it with my smart phone as a mic and it can serves as a great speaker phone.  Another use is a poor mans Karaoke speaker. Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'I can say that BT connectivity is solid, as I didnt detect any drop in connection', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the Bluetooth connectivity is solid and there was no drop in connection.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: "One thing for sure is that this speaker can put out serious sound for its size.  If loudness is what youre after, then this is it!  As to the sound quality, it is on par with other Bluetooth speakers. I was torn between this and the Klipsch Groove XXL speaker, so I bought both during the Black Friday sale. Putting side-by-side, the Klipsch produces a deep bass and clear highs compared to the Soundcore. It is clearly noticeable on the high notes and in the clarity of voice, known with Klipsch. That said, the Soundcore is no slough! To the point of my purchase, I want to keep one of the 2 as a winner but then end up keeping both because each performs so well in its strength. I neither need 2 large BT speakers nor can really afford to have both.  The Klipsch cant be used outdoors like the Soundcore, but does sound great; it is also heavier than the Soundcore. The Soundcore goes everywhere, even in the rain but doesnt have the fidelity of the Klipsch; it is lighter and rugged for portability than the Klipsch. Unfortunately, both units do not connect to multiple devices at once, so they can only be used with one device, which is a shame because each would be great for various entertainment settings. I can say that BT connectivity is solid, as I didnt detect any drop in connection. I got the Klipsch for $170 and the Soundcore for $129 on sale. So, clearly, the price advantage goes to the Soundcore. And that this price, it is hard to beat. As to the battery life, both speakers can go on forever, it seems. Overall, the Soundcore deserves a rating of 4.5 stars, but since there is no fraction in the rating, I round up with 5 stars."

QA_Content: The user mentioned that the Bluetooth connectivity is solid and there was no drop in connection.
Processed_QA_Content: Bluetooth connectivity is solid with no drop in connection.

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'portability of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'On the positive side, the speaker is quite portable and features a convenient carrying handle.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The speaker is portable and has a convenient carrying handle.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: "I purchased the Anker Soundcore Motion Boom Plus Outdoor Speaker with high hopes, given Ankers reputation for quality audio products. Unfortunately, my experience with this speaker has been less than satisfactory, leading me to give it a 2-star rating.", "The first issue I encountered was with the sound quality. Despite its promising name, the Boom Plus failed to deliver the depth and clarity I expected. The bass, while present, lacked punch and definition, which was particularly noticeable in outdoor settings. The highs and mids were muddled, failing to provide the crisp sound that is crucial for an enjoyable listening experience.", "Another disappointment was the build quality. The speaker doesnt feel as durable as advertised, which is a concern for an outdoor-oriented product. It seems susceptible to wear and tear, which makes me question its longevity and suitability for rugged use.", Battery life is also a concern. The speaker falls short of the promised playtime, needing frequent recharges even with moderate use. This is inconvenient, especially when using the speaker away from power sources., On the positive side, the speaker is quite portable and features a convenient carrying handle. The water-resistant design is a plus, making it suitable for poolside use or in light rain. However, these positives are overshadowed by the core issues of sound quality and build durability., "In conclusion, the Anker Soundcore Motion Boom Plus Outdoor Speaker doesnt live up to expectations, especially considering its price point. While it offers basic functionality and portability, the compromises in sound quality, build, and battery life are significant drawbacks. I would recommend potential buyers to consider other options if they are looking for a robust and high-fidelity outdoor speaker."

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'Individually theyre good sound quality for their size (15W). I personally opted for smaller wattage in favor of battery life. At about 75% volume on the Bluetooth MP3 player I hook one up to while Im at work, I can go a full 8 hours on a single charge. The USB-C port in the back can be hooked up to a power bank if you need to go longer and it will continue to play your audio even while charging.', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the speakers have good sound quality for their size and he opted for smaller wattage in favor of battery life. He also mentioned that he can go a full 8 hours on a single charge at about 75% volume on the Bluetooth MP3 player he hooks one up to while he is at work. The USB-C port in the back can be hooked up to a power bank if you need to go longer and it will continue to play your audio even while charging.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: "Great minds think alike, I guess. When these were on sale during the Black Friday and Cyber Monday seasonal shopping rush, I purchased one for myself and it turns out my younger brother purchased the very same one to give to me as a Christmas gift... so I have two! After reading through the specs, I noticed there was an option to pair the two of them together. Reading some of the comments people had left about how confusing it was or that it wasnt working at all, I was fascinated by the prospect of trying it out. Im a burnt-out, former I.T. guy, mind you, so this sort of technology doesnt intimidate me. I also had a reputation for reading manuals a little too thoroughly, which led to my ascertaining the speakers run in a master-slave configuration (called that in the manual). Basically, connect one speaker via Bluetooth to your Bluetooth device. Once connected, turn on your other speaker. Move it to within 1ft or 2ft and then press the top-most button on both speakers. Therell be about 6 seconds of blinking going on and then theyll chime and have an extra light on the top of each speaker. Congratulations, you now have full stereo sound capabilities!", "Individually theyre good sound quality for their size (15W). I personally opted for smaller wattage in favor of battery life. At about 75% volume on the Bluetooth MP3 player I hook one up to while Im at work, I can go a full 8 hours on a single charge. The USB-C port in the back can be hooked up to a power bank if you need to go longer and it will continue to play your audio even while charging. I havent used the TF port it has where you can plug in an up to 128gig SD card, but I would imagine it would be nice to have the option to playback directly and skip Bluetooth. Technically, the speakers battery life would increase quite a bit without all of the extra transmitting and receiving going on... might be worthwhile for those folks who need longer playback.", "At any rate, this speaker -- well speakers (plural) in my case -- works exceedingly well. I should mention it comes with a nice, relatively-durable strap attached and fits nicely in a caribiner attached to your belt loop of your denim jeans. The buttons could be painted something that contrasts well instead of the black-on-black that it is, but I think thats about it for dislikes and its an easy fix. A dab of nail polish or maybe a fine-tipped paint marker and youre good to go. Hope this  review helps someone and, yes, I do recommend this product!"

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'connectivity range of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'For example, it seems to have decent build quality, and pairing and streaming music to it from my Android phone was simple and worked flawlessly', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the speaker has decent build quality and pairing and streaming music to it from his Android phone was simple and worked flawlessly.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: There is a lot that the designers of this product got right.  For example, it seems to have decent build quality, and pairing and streaming music to it from my Android phone was simple and worked flawlessly.  However, there is glaring flaw that makes it a "no go" product for me, and that has to do with the output sound quality., The low frequency response is pretty good, but there is a very prominent cutoff of the high frequncies.  I haven't done any detailed testing, so this result is based solely on the sound I hear coming from the speaker.  Based on the sound, I would guess that there is significant attenuation (and by significant, I mean not audible to me at all) of all frequencies above maybe 5kHz.  Without these frequencies, everything sounds kind of "muffled" or "muddy".  This is a shame because otherwise, this seems like a really nice speaker.  Alas, since listening to music is what I intend to use it for, the missing high frequencies make it unusable for me., "(For anyone whos interested, my music source has a 5-band equalizer, and as expected, I can hear changes in the output of the speaker when I move the 4kHz slider, but there is no change at all when I adjust the 14kHz slider.  Based on that, it seems like there is a low pass filter with a cutoff frequency somewhere between 4kHz and 14kHz.)"

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'portability of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'The USB-C port in the back can be hooked up to a power bank if you need to go longer and it will continue to play your audio even while charging', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the speaker has a USB-C port in the back that can be hooked up to a power bank if needed to go longer and it will continue to play audio even while charging.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: "Great minds think alike, I guess. When these were on sale during the Black Friday and Cyber Monday seasonal shopping rush, I purchased one for myself and it turns out my younger brother purchased the very same one to give to me as a Christmas gift... so I have two! After reading through the specs, I noticed there was an option to pair the two of them together. Reading some of the comments people had left about how confusing it was or that it wasnt working at all, I was fascinated by the prospect of trying it out. Im a burnt-out, former I.T. guy, mind you, so this sort of technology doesnt intimidate me. I also had a reputation for reading manuals a little too thoroughly, which led to my ascertaining the speakers run in a master-slave configuration (called that in the manual). Basically, connect one speaker via Bluetooth to your Bluetooth device. Once connected, turn on your other speaker. Move it to within 1ft or 2ft and then press the top-most button on both speakers. Therell be about 6 seconds of blinking going on and then theyll chime and have an extra light on the top of each speaker. Congratulations, you now have full stereo sound capabilities!", "Individually theyre good sound quality for their size (15W). I personally opted for smaller wattage in favor of battery life. At about 75% volume on the Bluetooth MP3 player I hook one up to while Im at work, I can go a full 8 hours on a single charge. The USB-C port in the back can be hooked up to a power bank if you need to go longer and it will continue to play your audio even while charging. I havent used the TF port it has where you can plug in an up to 128gig SD card, but I would imagine it would be nice to have the option to playback directly and skip Bluetooth. Technically, the speakers battery life would increase quite a bit without all of the extra transmitting and receiving going on... might be worthwhile for those folks who need longer playback.", "At any rate, this speaker -- well speakers (plural) in my case -- works exceedingly well. I should mention it comes with a nice, relatively-durable strap attached and fits nicely in a caribiner attached to your belt loop of your denim jeans. The buttons could be painted something that contrasts well instead of the black-on-black that it is, but I think thats about it for dislikes and its an easy fix. A dab of nail polish or maybe a fine-tipped paint marker and youre good to go. Hope this  review helps someone and, yes, I do recommend this product!"

QA_Content: The user mentioned that the speaker has a USB-C port in the back that can be hooked up to a power bank if needed to go longer and it will continue to play audio even while charging.

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'compatibility of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'No easy way to sync up your computer, phones or other devices through the house and cycle through connecting with ease', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that there is no easy way to sync up your computer, phones or other devices through the house and cycle through connecting with ease.', 'sentiment': 'negative'}"
Review text: Great little speaker made by Anker!, Pros:, -Lightweight, -Easy to turn on with one hand (slide button for power on/off), -Excellent battery life (lasts me 2 to 3 days of fair use), Cons:, -AUTO POWER OFF -1 star, Not sure why an Anker engineer decided that an "Auto Power Off" was an excellent idea with no way to disable it. Not only can you not shut it off, but it\s timed so minuscule, (5 to 10 minutes of inactivity) it cant be used for anything that needs it on 24/7 (plugged in) or for pauses in audio use (YouTube/browsing and leaving comments); music is your only avenue. This forces you to power cycle the device, by sliding it off then back to on, then it has to re-sync (See con #2 below). Add this constant action up to 1000s of power offs, and I doubt the power button mechanism will survive the full products intended lifetime. So far its still solid, but who knows when a short might start to appear., -Bluetooth fighting -0.5 stars, No easy way to sync up your computer, phones or other devices through the house and cycle through connecting with ease. As soon as it powers on, it will try to sync with the last connected bluetooth device. If you have an aggressive device that scans actively and finds the speaker on, it will fight for that one connection. This leaves you with disabling all bluetooth devices that have it paired, just so the main device you want, gets to pair/connect., -Radio station, "Good luck navigating to your favorite station if you choose to use this. As another reviewer had stated, once you find it through the atrocious volume up/down buttons (must hold for 1.5 to 2 seconds before that mode skip, or scan is activated) be careful with adjusting the volume. Hold it down a moment to long and poof! Good luck with that one station that is .5 from another, you might not get it.", In the end, solid product with its shares of woes, but 4 stars I rate it. Since I dont use the radio at all, but just tested it out for this review, I took no stars off. And since there are no .5 stars to give, I just rounded it up. That auto shut off is the kicker though that one day may make me rip my hair out and buy another speaker, but the battery life is something I cant live without for such a lightweight, small packaged speaker.

Actual Response: "{'feature': 'portability of wireless-bluetooth-speakers', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'Just throw this thin in a bag and you are good to go', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user mentioned that the speaker is very portable and can be easily carried in a bag due to its thin size.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}"
Review text: \xa0Purchase price: £21.99 + Free PRIME delivery, Pros and Cons below, What a little speaker!! Bought as Christmas gift for someone who had been asking for one for some time, ANKER had to be the brand of choice. As you can see from the photos and video it emits a great sound all for being half the length of a biro pen! So 6 months in and the battery has no issues. Lasts a very long time on a single charge. Can be thrown into a bag and taken on the go. There are buttons on the device for volume, on/off, port for a micro SD card, 3.5mm jack, mode button and toggle switch. Just throw this thin in a bag and you are good to go. You can long press the + and - button to skip or go back a song., Pros:, + Great sound quality, + Just look at the size of it- so portable, + Has a weighted feel to it, very robust, + High quality speaker grill, + Soft base so it cant slide on a desk, + Comes with charging cable and very user friendly manual, + Every possible output, Bluetooth, Micro SD Card, 3.5mm jack, + Connects to phones, laptops, cameras, PCs - basically if you have any of the connectivity options in the pint above, you can connect to this speaker, + Buttons have a high quality press to them, Cons:, - Bluetooth connectivity - while it connects to phones very well and plays songs perfectly, if you are trying to watch a video, there is some delay in the audio which results in the video being out of sync which makes it a night mare for movies. Shame as if your primary speaker is currently a laptop or a phone as this would have been an upgrade, can always use the 3.5mm jack, - Would have been great if a small carry case was included, - Micro USB Type-B charging port, would have been great if it were Type-C, - Needs designated skip/previous song buttons. Holding down the +/- just takes those few seconds too long, - Small LCD screen would have been great for time or track length
